The 'islets of Langerhans' are the regions of the pancreas that contain its
endocrine (i.e., hormone-producing) cells. Discovered in 1869 by German
pathological anatomist Paul Langerhans at the age of 22, {{Cite journal
  | author = Langerhans P title = Beitrage zur mikroscopischen anatomie der
  | bauchspeichel druse journal = Inaugural-dissertation. Berlin: Gustav Lange
  | volume = issue = pages = year = 1869 pmid = doi = pmc =
}} the islets of Langerhans constitute approximately 1 to 2% of the mass
of the pancreas.
